How to Knead Dough and Why It's Important When You're Making a Yeasted Bread | Bon Appétit

And then you remember that just last week, you made focaccia that required no kneading at all.So what’s the point? And do you really need to do it for 10 entire minutes? I’m answering all of your kneading questions below:What does kneading do?Before you understand kneading, you’ve gotta understand gluten. When you mix wheat flour and water together, the proteins in the flour combine to form a gluten network. This structure is what gives bread dough the strength and elasticity to capture all the bubbles and burbles produced by yeast in order to grow fluffy, chewy, and light when baked.This magic happens all on its own, and for some breads (like focaccia) all you need is enough water and time to develop a strong gluten network. But other doughs, like the one for the Cinnamon-Date Sticky Buns, need some help to get there—and that help comes in the form of kneading.The amount of time you’re asked to knead the dough depends on its hydration level and the characteristics of the final product. When you knead you’re not only developing the gluten, but you’re also lining up those gluten strands into an orderly structure that’s strong and tight. Well-kneaded swirl buns will have a smooth surface and tight crumb, while no-knead focaccia is bumpy, with a wildly irregular cross section.Okay, so how do I do it?Kneading dough is as simple as pushing the dough away from you with the heel of your palm, folding it over itself with your fingers, and pulling it back. This repeated push-pull cross-knits the protein strands, developing a strong gluten net.Some recipes may tell you to knead on a lightly floured surface, while others specify a surface with no flour at all. It’s important to read the directions carefully because recipes are specifically formulated for a certain method. The wet, sticky dough in the Cinnamon-Date Sticky Buns, for example, is kneaded on an un-floured surface for a light and fluffy bread with a tender and open crumb.And how do I know when I’m done?A dough might start out lumpy and wet, but as you knead, it will grow smooth, supple, and springy—that’s how you know you’ve fully developed your gluten network and can stop kneading. Under-kneaded dough won’t rise properly because it doesn’t have the strength and elasticity to capture the gases produced by yeast—it'll bake up dry, crumbly, and dense.Always follow the visual cues in each specific recipe: If the recipe asks you to knead your dough until it passes the windowpane test (you can stretch the dough to be so thin, without tearing, that you can see light through it), then take it that far. But if your recipe instructs you to knead just until smooth, you won’t make a better bread through continued kneading. For most recipes, it’s hard to over-knead your dough by hand, but you do risk overheating it, and that could prematurely kickstart proofing.Follow the recipe and don’t be afraid to push your dough around a bit—you’ve gotta get that gluten in line.Ready for some practice?Cinnamon-Date Sticky BunsThese fluffy buttermilk-laced buns are filled with a cinnamon-scented date purée to capture all that gooey sticky bun glory without being overly sweet.View RecipeExplore Bon AppétitBasically BakingDoughRecipes you want to make.
